results.title: Serving People
results.creator_credit: Peter Quarry, Eve Ash and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Improving Service”.
Customers and clients want to be served in a positive way. Frontline staff should use greetings and names, show respect for unusual requests, be sensitive to cultural differences and overcome language barriers.

results.title: Supervising for Service
results.creator_credit: Peter Quarry, Eve Ash and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Improving Service”.
Supervisors need to support frontline staff in serving customers by providing on-going training, being available when problems arise, motivating staff and improving poor individual service performance.

results.title: Selecting for Service
results.creator_credit: Peter Quarry, Eve Ash and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Improving Service”.
Organisations have to select the right people to serve. Outlines six selection criteria and demonstrates selection techniques.

results.title: Getting organised to serve
results.creator_credit: Peter Quarry, Eve Ash and Seven Dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Improving Service”.
Organisations can get their “service mix” right by overhauling internal systems, removing service barriers, streamlining organisational structures and functions, and motivating staff to serve.

results.title: Matter of taste
results.creator_credit: David H. Gluck, Naomi Robin, James B. Maas, James B. Maas and David H. Gluck Productions and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human senses”.
Looks at the important role played by taste in the human body. Investigates the chemical reactions in papillae and how information is obtained and relayed to the brain and the taste identified as sweet, sour,salty or bitter.

results.title: In touch with the world
results.creator_credit: James B. Maas and David H. Gluck Productions and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human senses”.
Explains the functions of the human skin as a sense organ and the ability of the receptors to differentiate between at least five different kinds of sensations - touch, pressure, heat, cold and pain. Shows how the sense of touch has contributed to human development and adaptation of the human species to its environment.

results.title: On the nose
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human senses”.
An introduction to the sense of smell. Animation is used to illustrate the operations of the smell receptors in the nasal cavities and how this information is processed by the brain. Clearly defines the concept of smelling and recognition of odours.

results.title: Fiji - legacies of empire
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Dennis O'Rourke, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series looks at the Pacific islands, the traditions associated with them and issues that pose problems to them. This particular film examines the different aspects of life in Fiji. It notes the opinions of a patriarch of the hard-working Indian population and explores the co-existence of Hindus and Moslems who own less than a fifth of the land. Camera by Dennis O’Rourke and Joe Pickering.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Robertson, Dennis O’Rourke, Cinema Enterprises and Film Australia

results.title: A place of power in French Polynesia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series looks at the Pacific islands, the traditions associated with them and issues that pose problems to them. Tahiti is looked at in this particular film. Through the eyes of Karim, a Polynesian dancer, we glimpse the effects of western world influences and the effects of French and Church influences on Polynesian society and customs.
